subject: PPE
statement_full_text:
Q1
My drive to study PPE stems from its opportunity to shape my critical analysis and exploration through its multidisciplinary examination of world events, thought, and the art of argumentation. When I attended St John's College's PPE Study Day, Alison Hill's lecture on whether equality matters involved a utilisation of Rawl's vale of ignorance. I concluded that fairness in society requires not just the philosophical notion of equality but also the political facet of influence. The concept of a society where there is a stark inequality of wealth distribution, and not knowing where one would end up made me decide that there does lie responsibility for prosperous individuals and the government to facilitate a system of redistribution. This led me to read an academic article in the Attlee government's social policy. I was particularly drawn to the creation of the welfare state but I disagreed with the article's conclusion that these were 'modest reforms' and that the success in the past is 'making things difficult for us now'. This is because of the risk that come with 'going private' with healthcare that were exhibited to me in a BBC documentary: namely the inadequate facilities and staffing which does not guarantee recovery or survival and it can give false hope to patients. Therefore, the NHS should be greatly prized as a symbol of fairness due to its universal access.

Q2
My fascination for Utilitarianism originated from coming across the trolley problem in Religious Studies. I covered this further when completing Harvard University's MOOC on Justice, where I came across Jeremy Bentham's idea of Utilitarianism as maximising pleasure over pain in an attempt to maximise utility. Whilst I disagree that pleasure and pain can be measured effectively enough to be meaningful, if there were to measure a variable for the sake of deciding on policy, pleasure and pain ought to not be the only two aspects that should be considered when conducting cost benefit analysis by governments, for example. Humans contain a greater intellectual and emotional complexity to simply assert that these two variables are the most relevant and look at them in a binary manner.

In the process of completing the MOOC I was surprised to find that the result of the Phillip Moris study which was a cost benefit analysis for smoking in the Czech Republic led to the conclusion that there was a net finance gain of $147 million a year. Reading an academic article that critiqued this I was not surprised to find that there were erroneous assumptions that were made. As an inaugural recipient as the Ashmolean Economics tutorials at my school, I had argued in support in response to the question: 'Economics is wrong but sometimes useful' where I argued that the assumptions made in Economics can often lead to misleading conclusions which can lead to not getting closer to the truth and leaving the public with uncertainty, as was the case with HS2. The fact that Philip Moris used their philanthropy as a source of lobbying was counter-intuitive morally though it was economically justified on an individualistic basis. Answering Caius Explore's essay competition question on whether lobbying is good or bad for the economy and society I concluded that lobbying is especially bad for society as it leads to a degradation in societal welfare and that it harms the economy by decreasing productivity and increasing barriers to entry for new firms due to rent seeking that takes place. This diverts resources toward political influence according to Bombardini and Trebbi's paper on empirical models of lobbying.

Q3
Entering the St John's Poster competition on the theme of imitation, I pursued an exploration into my question of whether moral virtue can be developed through imitation alone. Whereas I originally strongly agreed with Aristotle's ideas in Nichomachean Ethics, that by observing and imitating role models one's character can be developed since "We become just by doing just acts", I no longer think that someone can be truly be seen as just only due to their outward actions. Intention has to conjoin the action. Kant's Categorial imperitative which incorporates reason and intention provides a better guideline for moral actions.

When I read Dharshini David's The Almighty Dollar, learning about China's investment in countries such as Ethiopia linked to the resistance against giving aid in the fear that this would create dependency. Whilst I think that tied aid is a means to exploit countries need of assistance, I think that prosperous individuals in prosperous countries have a responsibility to redistribute their wealth. This led to my curiosity in effective altruism where I wanted to know if its focus on rationality was effective in the sense of being able to harness donations. Thus, I conducted a project where I investigated the extent to which emotions influence giving. I concluded that giving should be celebrated and it should not be done so strictly as it will drive people away from this philosophy, and when emotion is utilised in the process of persuasion, it can encourage charitable giving.

Emotions can also be exploited. I witnessed this in the wake of the 2024 Summer riots that were the result of misinformation spreading rapidly through social media. In my entry for the Northeastern University essay competition answering "Digital technology is fundamentally changing politics. Discuss." I argued that through this medium of social media which virtually everyone has access to, transmitting information as well as visual imagery on a mass scale means that people can be propelled to irrationally cause destruction. The inflammatory language that is used plays on people's emotions and causes division. Listening to Politics Weekly's podcast episode about what we have learned a year on from the riots, I initially thought that there is not much that can be done because it would be too repressive to over-regulate social media. However, I was intrigued to find out that the Home Office sometimes does not inform local authorities of when they will move asylum seekers to local hotels, wheras when a local authority is informed then they can inform the citizens of the area. This discourse allows for more peace, demonstrating that accurate information getting to the public is essential in maintaining understanding between all parties.

PPE offers the discipline to pursue an understanding of the mechanisms that create a fair society and this real-world relevance motivates me.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My drive to study PPE stems from its opportunity to shape my critical analysis and exploration through its multidisciplinary examination of world events, thought, and the art of argumentation
feedback_items.your_feedback: Cut that entire first sentence. It adds absolutely nothing. Just start with when you attended the PPE study day.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start directly with: 'I attended St John's College PPE study day and listened to a lecture where Alison Hill concluded that equality matters...'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I concluded that fairness in society requires not just the philosophical notion of equality but also the political facet of influence
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'm not entirely sure what you mean by that. Do you just mean fairness needs equality and influence? It's not a strong point. You need to rewrite that and back it up with academic sources. Where did you get that from?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify what you mean specifically. Explain why you concluded that. Cite sources that led you to this conclusion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The concept of a society where there is stark inequality of wealth distribution and not knowing where one would end up made me decide that there does lie a responsibility for prosperous individuals and the government to facilitate a system of redistribution
feedback_items.your_feedback: This sentence is so long and wordy. I'm guessing you mean something like 'the wealthy and the government have responsibility to create a system to redistribute income.' But if you rewrite it like that, you'll see you've not actually explained why. Why do they have responsibility? That's not obvious - you need to say why you think that is the case.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Break into shorter sentences. State clearly: wealthy and government have responsibility to redistribute. Then explain WHY. Be specific about what you mean by 'system of redistribution' - income? wealth?

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was particularly drawn to the creation of the welfare state but I disagreed with the article's conclusion that these were 'modest reforms'
feedback_items.your_feedback: What are you drawn to? Why are you drawn to the creation of it? Which part? You agree with it? Why do you agree with it? It's not really explained. What modest reforms? You haven't told me. And 'the success in the past is making things difficult for us now' is meaningless unless it's in support of a point. You haven't made a point, so it's random.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain specifically what aspects of the welfare state drew you in and why. Detail what the reforms were. Build your argument before concluding.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This is because of the risk that come with 'going private' with healthcare that were exhibited to me in a BBC documentary: namely the inadequate facilities and staffing which does not guarantee recovery or survival and it can give false hope to patients
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's not actually an economics, philosophy, or political point, to be honest. It's fine to use a BBC documentary to say this is where you first learned about it, but then say you started here and backed it up by looking at actual papers and NHS reports. Maybe bring in some data.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Use the documentary as a starting point only. Follow up with academic papers, NHS reports, actual data to support your argument about healthcare.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Therefore, the NHS should be greatly prized as a symbol of fairness due to its universal access
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's your view, but not backed up. The whole paragraph has interesting topic and you've clearly done research, but you need to shape it better. You need a clear conclusion with clear support of your points.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Build supporting evidence before stating this conclusion. Use academic sources and data to demonstrate why universal access equals fairness.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My fascination for utilitarianism originated from coming across the trolley problem in Religious Studies
feedback_items.your_feedback: Just cut that sentence. Start with: 'I completed a Harvard University MOOC on justice, which discussed the idea of utilitarianism.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete and start directly with the MOOC content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Whilst I disagree that pleasure and pain can be measured effectively enough to be meaningful
feedback_items.your_feedback: You can't just disagree with something unless you're gonna back it up and say why you disagree. That can be with another paper, an idea, a theory, but you can't just state that and assume they will have the same opinion. Even disregarding that you haven't backed it up, I'm not totally sure why you disagree.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Support your disagreement with philosophical arguments or papers. Explain specifically why measurement is problematic. What alternative framework do you propose?

feedback_items.weak_passage: Humans contain a greater intellectual and emotional complexity to simply assert that these two variables are the most relevant
feedback_items.your_feedback: What do you mean by intellectual complexity? What are these other variables you're talking about? Like, actually give me specific examples and give me a specific better case.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Define intellectual and emotional complexity concretely. Name specific variables that should be considered. Provide examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In the process of completing the MOOC I was surprised to find that the result of the Phillip Moris study which was a cost benefit analysis for smoking in the Czech Republic led to the conclusion that there was a net finance gain of $147 million a year
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole sentence which is like 3.5 lines long, I would change to: 'A cost-benefit study by Philip Morris in the Czech Republic found there was a net gain of $147 million.' Is that to the economy? In which year? Over how many years? Not specific enough, not enough explanation about which point you're making.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Shorten dramatically. Specify: gain to what/whom? Which year? Over how long? Be precise with the economic claim.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading an academic article that critiqued this I was not surprised to find that there were erroneous assumptions that were made
feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to tell me what the article was. You don't tell me what the erroneous assumptions were. Why are you not surprised? I find that quite surprising - why that there were mistakes in the study? Was there something missed? Something purposely missed? In studies you have to pick and choose what you measure and it's not always an error - that's done purposely.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Name the article. Specify the erroneous assumptions. Explain why you weren't surprised and demonstrate understanding of methodological choices vs. errors.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I had argued in support in response to the question: 'Economics is wrong but sometimes useful' where I argued that the assumptions made in Economics can often lead to misleading conclusions which can lead to not getting closer to the truth and leaving the public with uncertainty, as was the case with HS2
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't say the title of it. Just say what your conclusion was. You can't just say 'as was the case with HS2.' You can't assume they know that. You can't assume they're going to make the same conclusions. Clearly state what your conclusion was and what led you to believe or get to that point.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove essay title, save space. Explain specifically what happened with HS2 and how it demonstrates your point about misleading assumptions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The fact that Philip Moris used their philanthropy as a source of lobbying was counter-intuitive morally though it was economically justified on an individualistic basis
feedback_items.your_feedback: Is it counter-intuitive? You need to explain that more. 'Economically justified on an individualistic basis' - all of these are very big statements with not much backing. You haven't explained it enough that I even know what you're thinking.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain why this is counter-intuitive. Define what you mean by 'economically justified on individualistic basis.' Support these claims.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I concluded that lobbying is especially bad for society as it leads to a degradation in societal welfare and that it harms the economy by decreasing productivity and increasing barriers to entry for new firms due to rent seeking that takes place. This diverts resources toward political influence according to Bombardini and Trebbi's paper
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's not a bad conclusion, it's just kind of like OK, but why, but how, but what's your point? You haven't mentioned exactly why they reached that conclusion, and you can't name drop a paper without developing it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain the mechanisms in detail. Summarize Bombardini and Trebbi's key arguments and evidence. Show your analytical engagement with the paper.

feedback_items.weak_passage: We become just by doing just acts...I no longer think that someone can be truly be seen as just only due to their outward actions
feedback_items.your_feedback: Why do you no longer think that? I don't know. You say intent has to conjoin the action and Kant's categorical imperative is a better guideline. Why is Kant's better? You need to explain that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain what changed your mind about Aristotle. Detail why intention matters philosophically. Explain specifically why Kant's framework is superior.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I think that prosperous individuals in prosperous countries have a responsibility to redistribute their wealth
feedback_items.your_feedback: Why? Why should they be responsible? You're assuming that people are all gonna agree that that's the right thing to do. You need to argue for this position.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Build philosophical or economic argument for this responsibility claim. Engage with opposing views. Support with theory or evidence.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I conducted a project where I investigated the extent to which emotions influence giving. I concluded that giving should be celebrated and it should not be done so strictly as it will drive people away from this philosophy
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'd like to hear more about that project. You just give the conclusion. You need to talk about the actual things that you found, not just summarize the outcome.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Detail your methodology. Present key findings. Explain how the evidence led to your conclusion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Emotions can also be exploited. I witnessed this in the wake of the 2024 Summer riots
feedback_items.your_feedback: That emotions can be exploited is true. It's not particularly interesting, it's just true. The whole riots thing I'm a little bit confused by.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop this into a more sophisticated point or remove it. If keeping it, explain the specific mechanisms of emotional exploitation with evidence.

feedback_items.weak_passage: answering 'Digital technology is fundamentally changing politics. Discuss.'
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've named the essay title, which we don't like. You need to just say the conclusion because it saves space.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove essay title. State your conclusion directly. Use the saved space for better content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: through this medium of social media which virtually everyone has access to, transmitting information as well as visual imagery on a mass scale means that people can be propelled to irrationally cause destruction
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't think that's a particularly interesting point, to be honest. But if you're going to put that, at least you need to give some evidence and explanation.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either make this more sophisticated with specific mechanisms and evidence, or remove it entirely.

feedback_items.weak_passage: it would be too repressive to over-regulate social media
feedback_items.your_feedback: What is too repressive? You haven't said what it is. You're leaving things hanging without proper explanation.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify what regulatory measures you're referring to. Explain why they would be too repressive. Complete your thoughts.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You have so many ideas, and because you have so many ideas, a lot of them are underdeveloped and not supported. You've got too many essays - at most you want to discuss like two essays. You need to choose which ones you found most interesting and cut the rest.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose your strongest 2 essays. Cut other examples. Use the space to properly develop your remaining points with full support and explanation.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Your writing style needs work - you need to make sentences a lot shorter and more simple. You need to get to the point quicker. You can't leave things open-ended. You can't just say it or that or this and assume we're gonna know. Shorten sentences as a habit - is the sentence clear? If not, rewrite it. Make it shorter, make it in active tense.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Break long sentences into shorter ones. Use active voice (e.g., 'I entered this competition' not 'Entering the...'). Complete every thought - don't leave assumptions.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to include more sources. When you mention $147 million effect, you need to say on what and when. When you say this is good or bad, you need to say why. You can't just leave a conclusion and run away.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Every claim needs support. Every source needs development. Every conclusion needs reasoning. Be specific with all data and citations.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't think you need to spend a lot of time on this. You've got all the information and you've done a huge amount of things. You don't need to go out and reread things. All you need to do is rewrite this a little bit - cut some stuff, choose which essays were most interesting, develop supporting evidence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: First take this as a first draft. Pull out the points you're most keen on, simplify, and expand the supporting evidence. You can send sections one at a time (Q1, then Q2, then Q3).

subject: Veterinary Medicine
statement_full_text:
Question 1: Why do you want to study this course or subject?
I discovered my love for animals when I was paired with Ruby during Equine Therapy. Caring for her gave me a sense of purpose and direction through challenging times of my health. While there, I also completed AQA award scheme certificates about horse stables, management and grooming which laid a foundation of curiosity and knowledge into the veterinary profession. I witnessed and experienced the impact animals have on supporting well-being in humans. The sense of achievement I gained from relating with Ruby has left me with compassion and has driven my interest to pursue a veterinary career.

Question 2: How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?
I enjoy independently researching different diseases like Hemangiosarcoma in dogs once I discovered that my friends dog struggled with it. The limited treatment options and the fast growth tumor on the lining of blood vessels led me to read Jennings and Premanandan's 'Veterinary Histology', which explained the structure of blood vessels. I learnt about the importance of the endothelial cells, their function and the tumor makes the endothelial cells unable to hold blood well in the vessels allowing them to rupture and bleed which can cause death. By reading James Heriot's book 'The God Lord Made Them All' I was particularly struck by the challenges and responsibility of transporting animals abroad. Having to navigate global regulations and ensure animal welfare, how a vet plays a vital role in protecting animal rights. I watched a documentary, 'The Secret Life of a Penguin'. This educated me on how penguins must adapt to their environment during the harsh weather changes bringing the realization that a vet needs to understand normal animal behaviors in their natural habitats before dealing with sick animals to compare the difference.

Question 3: What else have you done to prepare outside of education and why are these experiences useful?
Netball has improved my teamwork, while boxing and personal training keep me fit, important for the stress relief a vet constantly needs.

I have actively sought work experiences in the veterinary sector, from lambing and working in a dairy farm to volunteering at horse stables, city farms and small animal hospitals.

During Lambing work experience I saw the growth of lambs and their different development stages, seeing their day growth, as well as assisting with births, monitoring ewes, bottle feeding and tube feeding the weaker lambs. All increased my knowledge of animal husbandry and it reinforced to me that I work well within a team to ensure the sheep get the best possible care. I particularly enjoyed experiencing the unpredictability of farming, seeing the urgency of problems that come during lambing and solving them. It all left me feeling fulfilled, excited and determined to become a vet. I also realised that I would love to work on an independent farm, where animals are looked after well.

At the RVC I completed The Sutton Trust Summer School, I particularly enjoyed learning about the journey that animals had from being rescued and unwell to full recovery. I enjoyed learning about reptiles, which was a new experience for me and which enabled me to improve my research skills when I researched egg binding, sourcing several reliable references and preparing a presentation.

A Tibial Plateau Levelling Osteotomy was fascinating; I saw how carefully they placed the screws and the complexity of the surgery. I loved problem solving, seeing how things fit together and how a few screws can make such a difference to a dog's mobility and quality of life. I was disturbed by the neutering of a pregnant homeless cat. The vets and nurses explained this was a common procedure, despite the danger of complications like hernia. This highlighted for me the ethical dilemmas vets must confront. Another cat in liver and renal failure received 4 days' palliative care; putting her to sleep was the kindest option but her owners found this deeply upsetting. I realized how the vet must balance the welfare needs of the animal and those of the owners, showing compassion and empathy throughout the whole process. Taking the paw prints and shaving some of the fur felt very meaningful, keeping the cat's memory alive. All this fires my ambition to serve and protect animals in a career as a vet.

feedback_items.your_feedback: It's so much better now that it's basically finished. I've just corrected a couple of technical details and put in brackets like 3 places where you could add a couple of things. It looks ready and really good. Especially that third section is really strong.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add minor details where indicated in brackets. Consider specifying Ruby's breed in opening. Mention a source when discussing egg binding research. Specify where you presented egg binding findings.
feedback_items.strong_passage: All this fires my ambition to serve and protect animals in a career as a vet
feedback_items.why_strong: The third section with work experience is particularly strong - shows depth of practical engagement, ethical reflection, and genuine passion.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The first section repeats quite a lot of the ideas. If you needed to cut anything for character count, I would do a little bit of work in that first section.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If over character limit, condense the opening section about Ruby and equine therapy which has some repetitive content.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I've made technical corrections throughout. Added suggestions in brackets for: specifying Ruby's breed, mentioning a source for egg binding research, and specifying where you presented findings.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Review bracketed suggestions: breed specification, source citation, presentation venue.

feedback_items.weak_passage: maybe specify the breed here e.g. a six year old Thoroughbred
feedback_items.your_feedback: Could add specific detail about Ruby's breed to make the opening more concrete and memorable.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider adding: 'Ruby, a six-year-old Thoroughbred' or similar breed specification.

feedback_items.weak_passage: sourcing several reliable references
feedback_items.your_feedback: Could be worth mentioning a specific source for the egg binding research.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Name at least one of the reliable sources you used for egg binding research.

feedback_items.weak_passage: and presented my findings to (mention where you showed this)
feedback_items.your_feedback: Should specify where or to whom you presented the egg binding research findings.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add the venue/audience for your presentation (e.g., 'to the summer school cohort' or similar).

feedback_items.weak_passage: Taking the paw prints and shaving some of the fur felt very meaningful, keeping the cat's memory alive. Cut this sentence if you need to for character count!
feedback_items.your_feedback: This sentence about paw prints could be cut if you need space for character count, though it is meaningful.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If over character limit, this is safe to remove without losing essential content.

feedback_items.strong_passage: I was disturbed by the neutering of a pregnant homeless cat. The vets and nurses explained this was a common procedure, despite the danger of complications like hernia. This highlighted for me the ethical dilemmas vets must confront
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows mature understanding of ethical complexity in veterinary medicine. Demonstrates ability to grapple with difficult decisions rather than oversimplifying.

feedback_items.strong_passage: Another cat in liver and renal failure received 4 days' palliative care; despite her owner's pain, it was clear that putting her to sleep was the kindest option. This has given me valuable insight into how a vet must balance the welfare needs of the animal and those of the owners, showing compassion and empathy throughout the whole process
feedback_items.why_strong: Excellent demonstration of understanding the complexity of veterinary decision-making, including communication with owners and end-of-life care. Shows empathy for all parties involved.

subject: Veterinary Medicine
statement_full_text:
I love animals and see a career as a vet as the ideal way to care for and protect them. I discovered my love for animals when in equine therapy I was paired with a horse, Ruby, and learned about equine care and common diseases. The compassion, care and bond I have developed during work experience has driven my interest and sense of purpose. As a vet I hope to take full responsibility for the animals in my care, choosing the medication and correct treatment.

A-Level Biology and Chemistry have given me a thorough grounding in human anatomy and physiology, allowing me to identify specific comparisons in different types of animals. Maths is training my quantitative problem-solving skills. I enjoy independently researching different diseases like Hemangiosarcoma in dogs. The limited treatment options and the fast growth tumour on the lining of blood vessels led me to read Jennings and Premanandan's 'Veterinary Histology', which explained the structure of blood vessels. I went on to research the Maltipoo breed and common diseases of dogs. James Heriot's 'Every Living Thing', 'The Good Lord Made Them All' and 'All Creatures Great and Small' and his TV shows increased my interest, as did a Disney Plus documentary, 'The Secret Life of Penguins'. I have also completed an online course on 'Do you have what it takes to be a veterinarian?'

Netball has improved my teamwork, while boxing and personal training keep me fit, important for the stress relief a vet constantly needs. On lambing work experience I increased my empathy with animals, tube- and bottle-fed some sick lambs, and injected calcium and magnesium into a sick lamb. When a lamb was born, we sprayed iodine in the umbilical cord to prevent infection. I saw a ewe reject her lamb, which was fostered by another lamb, after rubbing the amniotic fluid to get the new ewe to accept the lamb.

At the RVC's SSTS, I learnt about reptiles, spent a day in the farm learning about dairy cows, the volume of milk produced, and horn removal. I also learnt how to hold a chicken correctly to examine the feet and wings. I discovered the 6 basics of life: light, shelter, food, water, air and space. I learnt to pin down sheep to check the hoofs and udder, and did body scoring, using their teeth to tell the age. At equine I learnt how to put a headcollar and rug onto a horse, practising first on a mannequin before performing the procedure on a horse. I saw the various diagnosis images (CT, Xray, MRI and scintigraphy) offered in the equine referral hospital and examined ligaments, tendons and bones in the horse's legs. I listened to the horse's heart, lungs and bowels and learnt how to examine a horse for temperature, heart rate, breathing rate. On a house projection about snakes, I researched egg binding and improved my research skills. In the clinical-skills lab I practised bandaging a mannequin dog, practised doing the surgeon knot and learnt how to gown up and put on gloves post-sterilization.

A TPLO was fascinating; I saw how carefully they placed the screws and the complexity of the surgery. I loved the problem solving, seeing how things fit together and how a few screws can make such a difference to a dog's mobility and quality of life. I was disturbed by the neutering of a pregnant homeless cat. The vets and nurses explained this was a common procedure, despite the danger of complications like hernia. This highlighted for me the ethical dilemmas vets must confront. Another cat in liver and renal failure received 4 days' palliative care; putting her to sleep was the kindest option but her owners found this deeply upsetting. I realized how the vet must balance the welfare needs of the animal and those of the owners, showing compassion and empathy throughout the whole process. Taking the paw prints and shaving some of the fur felt very meaningful, keeping the cat's memory alive. All this fires my ambition to serve and protect animals in a career as a vet.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I enjoy independently researching different diseases like Hemangiosarcoma in dogs. The limited treatment options and the fast growth tumour on the lining of blood vessels led me to read Jennings and Premanandan's 'Veterinary Histology', which explained the structure of blood vessels
feedback_items.your_feedback: For veterinary histology and the James Herriot series and Secret Life of Penguins and the online course - there's not quite enough development. If you could do 2 or 3 more sentences per source, that would be fantastic. Explain one slightly technical thing or write as much as you want because I can help you cut it down.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: For each source, write 3-4 sentences: what the book/source was overall exploring, explain one slightly technical thing you learned, say why you found it interesting. Then tutor will help cut down.

feedback_items.weak_passage: James Heriot's 'Every Living Thing', 'The Good Lord Made Them All' and 'All Creatures Great and Small' and his TV shows increased my interest, as did a Disney Plus documentary, 'The Secret Life of Penguins'. I have also completed an online course on 'Do you have what it takes to be a veterinarian?'
feedback_items.your_feedback: For each of these things - the Herriot series, the penguin documentary, and the online course - you need 3 to 4 sentences per source explaining what you learned and why it interested you. Just listing them adds nothing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop each source properly: what did you learn? What was particularly interesting? How did it deepen your understanding? Write more than needed and tutor will help cut.

feedback_items.your_feedback: In your particular case, I would recommend you spend 2 or 3 sentences explaining you went through some stuff, but you're now on track to do this and feel very strongly that you're going to be an excellent student at university. When students have unconventional situations, they need to give context because the personal statement shows why you'll be a good student.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add 2-3 sentences: acknowledge unconventional academic journey, explain current status, demonstrate readiness for university. Your past might explain why you'll be a better student in the future, and if past grades don't reflect what kind of student you are, give that context.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The work experience section just needs cutting down a bit - it's a little bit long but just needs reorganisation rather than removal of content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reorganize the extensive work experience section to be more concise. Keep the strong content but present it more efficiently.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You've got a lot of good elements and a lot of work experience which is very strong and will serve you well. Your love for veterinary medicine definitely comes through. But it's not quite finished yet. I can't tell you what to cut until we've got the full expansion of the underdeveloped sections.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: First expand the two sections (source development + personal context), then either: (1) receive full feedback and work on it yourself, or (2) let tutor do the cutting and organizing, then you add your writing style. You choose which approach.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You have a lot on your plate, so tutor is happy to do the cutting and organizing for you after you send expanded sections. The only thing you'd have to do is put your own writing style into it. It sounds like you absolutely love this degree and tutor wants to see you succeed.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand the two sections identified, then let tutor know if you want: full feedback to work on yourself, OR tutor to structure it and you just add your writing style.

feedback_items.strong_passage: A TPLO was fascinating; I saw how carefully they placed the screws and the complexity of the surgery. I loved the problem solving, seeing how things fit together and how a few screws can make such a difference to a dog's mobility and quality of life
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows genuine intellectual curiosity about veterinary procedures, appreciation for surgical precision, and understanding of practical outcomes for animals.

feedback_items.strong_passage: I was disturbed by the neutering of a pregnant homeless cat...This highlighted for me the ethical dilemmas vets must confront. Another cat in liver and renal failure received 4 days' palliative care; putting her to sleep was the kindest option but her owners found this deeply upsetting. I realized how the vet must balance the welfare needs of the animal and those of the owners
feedback_items.why_strong: Demonstrates mature understanding of veterinary ethics, shows ability to handle emotionally difficult situations, and recognizes the complexity of balancing animal welfare with owner emotions.

subject: Sustainability
statement_full_text:
When I think of sustainability, I do not picture solar panels or recycling; I think of a person, Gro Harlem Brundtland. As Norway's first female Prime Minister, former Director of WHO, and author of Our Common Future (Oxford University Press, 1987), she has been a trailblazer for current and future sustainability professionals—and a personal role model to me. Her work made me realise how sustainability is the backbone of Scandinavian culture, and with my curiosity, I wanted to explore further beyond what felt familiar to learn how sustainability was conceptualised abroad.

I therefore left my small hometown in northern Norway and have so far studied and worked across three continents, and learned to speak in a foreign language. This has allowed me to explore two key aspects: 1) how sustainability is practised globally across cultures, and 2) how I see myself as being a part of making impactful, positive change for current and future generations.

My journey began in high school, where I co-founded a youth business offering eco-friendly interior design. It was the first time I saw how values and perceptions shape sustainable choices, and how they vary amongst individuals. This set me on a quest to explore how sustainability is understood and practised globally. I therefore decided to leave the comfort of the small town I grew up in, Bodø, and move to the United States to enhance my academic English skills and immerse myself in international perspectives. There, I joined the Hawaiian Oceans project, researching ocean plastic pollution.

One vivid image from this project stayed with me—birds lying dead in their nests, their guts exposed and filled with plastic items they had eaten. Witnessing this made me question why sustainability initiatives succeed or fail, and it also led me to reflect on my own footprint and impact on nature. It sparked my interest in the role of communicating change, overcoming cultural biases, and the role of institutions in facilitating applied action. This marked the beginning of a growing self-awareness that would come to shape my academic and professional path.

Upon returning to Norway, I was eager to build professional experience while developing practical leadership skills. I joined L'Oréal, progressing to Counter Manager within 2 months, and to acting Domestic Brand Manager 1.5 years later. In these roles, I cultivated a leadership style emphasising active listening, individual strengths, and values-based motivation. During this time, the adoption of the Paris Agreement served as a crucial reminder of the challenges I had witnessed in Hawaii, prompting me to explore environmental management at an academic level.

To pursue this academic ambition, I relocated to Australia, a new continent, to further deepen my understanding of international perspectives. There, I undertake a Bachelor of Environmental Management at the University of Queensland (UQ). UQ's strong global reputation and top-ranked environmental faculty provided an exhilarating environment where I honed my research techniques, critical thinking, and time management skills.

While my early results reflected the challenge of adjusting to a new academic environment shaped by COVID-19, compounded by navigating the demands of studying with dyslexia, I steadily improved and ultimately achieved consistent high distinctions and distinctions as I grew in confidence and ability. Building on this, I completed an honours thesis exploring public perceptions of fossil fuels and decarbonisation policies. This research deepened my understanding of behavioural psychology, social identity, and policy resistance. It revealed a critical gap between ambitious Net Zero and Sustainable Development (NZSD) initiatives, and the willingness of certain demographic groups and organisations to embrace them.

This experience reinforced my belief that human-centred frameworks and adaptive communication are essential for translating technical sustainability strategies into meaningful, widely accepted action. It also made me recognise the need for emotionally intelligent leadership.

I therefore joined the LeadHers Program at UQ — a leadership program for women. This experience reshaped my view of leadership as not merely positional, but as the capacity to influence through clarity, empathy, and purpose. I got to practise this while serving as the team leader for a large-scale group project, where empathy was key to successfully guiding the team through collaborative challenges—resulting in high distinction.

Furthermore, I was eager to apply what I had learned academically and intellectually in a corporate environment. I interned at Queensland Trust for Nature, where I developed an interactive presentation for South Bank Corporation's precinct masterplan, proposing new built environment features deeply rooted in the UN's Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The presentation was so well-received by the corporation that it led to a role in their team to assist with integrating the SDGs into biodiversity and decarbonisation planning.

Balancing rigorous academic demands with corporate responsibilities during this period further strengthened my resilience and ability to manage priorities, resulting in graduation with a first-class honours degree, the Dean's Commendation Award, and a role as an environmental consultant at Arup.

At Arup, I have been recognised for my ability to translate complex technical data into strategic narratives for multidisciplinary teams. As co-chair of the OvaGreen committee, I initiate impactful action such as improving waste stream communication, which earned me a nomination for Arup's Sustainability Award. As co-chair of the Equality, Diversity, and Inclusion committee, I work to implement reproductive leave and improve resources for neurodivergent employees. This has allowed me to practice inclusive leadership, supporting environmental, social, and economic sustainability.

To further enhance my professional insights, I joined the Environment Institute of Australia and New Zealand (EIANZ), regularly attending expert panel Q&A sessions where I appreciate both industry insight and stories about personal growth. Additionally, independent readings like Dan Ariely's Misbelief and podcasts like The Circular Economy Show have enriched my perspectives on how different groups of people perceive information, cognitive biases and discussions on making circular behaviour irresistible.

Additionally, I sought out conversations with sustainability professionals at leading global companies, including L'Oréal and IKEA, to gain direct insight into what skillsets they will need in the next decade from future NZSD professionals, which has refined my understanding of the landscape I aspire to influence. This intellectual curiosity reflects my ability to critically engage with complex interdisciplinary knowledge and apply it to real-world NZSD challenges.

Building on these experiences, I recognise that despite global progress, substantial gaps remain, particularly in translating NZSD intent into widely embraced societal and organisational practices. My professional, academic and leadership experiences have taught me the urgent need for creative solutions and effective communication that bridge NZSD intent with behavioural acceptance, as well as the need to recognise how a modern world where AI is embracing our lives, emotional intelligence needs to be embraced in leadership.

My experiences and ambitions lead me to Oxford's MSc in Sustainability, Enterprise, and the Environment (SEE), which offers precisely the interdisciplinary environment, robust enterprise engagement, and practical methodologies I seek — particularly the Enterprise Forum and Business Case Seminars. Learning alongside leading experts and peers will equip me to holistically address today's sustainability challenges as a capable and influential leader. At Oxford, I aim to deepen my understanding of the groups we seek to influence and develop well-adapted solutions for large-scale NZSD initiatives, such as the European Green Deal (EU's continental net-zero strategy).

I eagerly anticipate this next chapter as I am not just well-equipped and prepared to devote the time, effort and skill needed to continue Oxford's pioneering work—I am also guided by Brundtland's principles of "meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs".

feedback_items.weak_passage: My journey began in high school, where I co-founded a youth business offering eco-friendly interior design...I therefore decided to leave the comfort of the small town I grew up in, Bodø, and move to the United States...There, I joined the Hawaiian Oceans project...Upon returning to Norway, I was eager to build professional experience...I joined L'Oréal, progressing to Counter Manager
feedback_items.your_feedback: The journey to university is very interesting, but it's not as interesting or relevant as some of the other things. I think there's storytelling from where you became interested and went to L'Oréal as brand manager - I'm not sure. I'd probably skip ahead to the university to be honest. That whole middle section, if you could narrow that and reduce it to about 2-3 sentences, that would be the place to lose some words.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense the high school through L'Oréal section dramatically - aim for 2-3 sentences total. Skip ahead to university. This is the easiest place to cut words.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This has allowed me to practice inclusive leadership, supporting environmental, social, and economic sustainability
feedback_items.your_feedback: Throughout, a lot of the time you're doing summary sentences and you don't need them as much because you've actually explained pretty well in your experience how you have those skills. For example: 'this has allowed me to practise inclusive leadership' or 'the intellectual curiosity reflects my ability to critically engage with complex interdisciplinary knowledge'.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove or drastically reduce these summary/reflection sentences. Your experiences already demonstrate these qualities - you don't need to state them explicitly. Cut these to save valuable space.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My professional, academic, and leadership experiences have taught me the urgent need for creative solutions and effective communication that bridge NZSD intent with behavioural acceptance
feedback_items.your_feedback: You include these summary sentences once or twice which is fine, but at the level you've included some of these, it takes up valuable space. I understand why you feel you need to put them in, but I think once or twice is fine. You're trying to tell them you have exactly all the skills they're looking for, but that comes across fine in your experiences and work anyway.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Limit yourself to one or two summary sentences maximum in the entire statement. Let your experiences speak for themselves.

feedback_items.weak_passage: independent readings like Dan Ariely's Misbelief and podcasts like The Circular Economy Show have enriched my perspectives on how different groups of people perceive information, cognitive biases and discussions on making circular behaviour irresistible
feedback_items.your_feedback: Because it's an Oxford master's degree, they want to see more on the academic side and academic curiosity. Aside from your thesis, there's not a lot of development of theories. This mention of Dan Ariely and podcasts is somewhat of a summary and not quite enough. What they will want to see is understanding of the academic subject, whereas you focus a bit on soft skills and less on expanding theories and developing academic ideas.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Go to the course page, look at tutors in charge of admissions, check their CVs/blogs/papers. Find interesting recent papers in the field. Discuss research you've read, what you think about it, develop the theories and innovations. Add a proper academic section exploring recent developments in research.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I think you could reduce down some of the experiences to shorten it a tiny bit. You've got a lot of focus on soft skills and less on academic ideas. For an Oxford masters, you need that slight twist to strengthen it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add a section that's more academic - exploring recent innovations or developments in research and the subject area from an academic perspective. This would greatly strengthen this for Oxford specifically.

feedback_items.your_feedback: First off, it was a really interesting read. It looks like you've done a lot of cool things. Apart from being above word count, I think it's very decent. There's just a couple of things from the Oxford perspective that I think are missing a little bit. As a whole, the whole thing is very well written just as an actual piece of writing, and you've clearly done all the right things.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Summary of changes: (1) Cut pre-university storytelling to 2-3 sentences, (2) Remove most summary/reflection sentences, (3) Add substantial academic section with engagement with recent research and theories in the field.

feedback_items.strong_passage: I completed an honours thesis exploring public perceptions of fossil fuels and decarbonisation policies. This research deepened my understanding of behavioural psychology, social identity, and policy resistance. It revealed a critical gap between ambitious Net Zero and Sustainable Development (NZSD) initiatives, and the willingness of certain demographic groups and organisations to embrace them
feedback_items.why_strong: Strong academic research with clear intellectual contribution. Shows ability to identify gaps in current approaches and engage with behavioral and social dimensions of sustainability.

feedback_items.strong_passage: At Arup, I have been recognised for my ability to translate complex technical data into strategic narratives for multidisciplinary teams. As co-chair of the OvaGreen committee, I initiate impactful action such as improving waste stream communication, which earned me a nomination for Arup's Sustainability Award
feedback_items.why_strong: Demonstrates practical application of skills in professional setting with recognition. Shows leadership and ability to create tangible impact.

subject: Economics
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course/subject?

My earliest role models had always shown an eagerness to know more, thus prompting me to have the same attitude. Naturally, this led to an acute interest in all things philosophical. To me, philosophy seeks to combat willful ignorance, forcing individuals to seek liberation from a life of delusion. It forces expansion of the mind through constant questioning. In philosophy, there is no absolute truth, only arguments for each side. This subjectivity is what deepened my interest in it; I am able to ponder concepts for hours on end without running out of perspectives. Throughout my academic life, this need to know more continued, and so when it came time to choose my A-level subjects, I wanted to pick something that would offer the same intellectual stimulation that philosophy did; leading me to pick psychology.

Having little to no knowledge on this subject, I found approaches to explaining what drives behaviour particularly fascinating. The contrast between the Humanistic approach and the Cognitive approach let me understand how far psychological research has come, and how much further it can go.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course/subject?

Studying A-level Psychology has changed my perspective in observing daily interactions. In understanding behaviour, I am able to apply behaviourist explanations of behaviour such as classical or operant conditioning. A-level Psychology has allowed me to rationalise behaviour of not only others but my own, using psychological concepts. It has given me perspective in understanding there may be several causes for an individual's choices. Freud's theory of psychosexual stages explains development from infancy to adulthood, giving me insight into people's actions, and how they are potentially rooted in early childhood experiences.

Similarly, A-level Philosophy has nurtured my naturally inquisitive mind, allowing me to observe reality through the eyes of the greatest minds in history. Debating rationalism vs empiricism has triggered me to question what the primary source of knowledge truly is. This has inspired me to read through the works of Plato and Aristotle in their differing understandings of reality, and use this knowledge in debates of a priori and a posteriori knowledge.

My A-level subjects have greatly helped me to improve my analytical skills. Teaching me to constantly be thorough in my explanations, I leave no stone unturned. More specifically, A-level Philosophy has taught me true evaluative skills, demonstrating that an argument can always be made the other way. Psychology has also been extremely useful in teaching me how to conceptualise knowledge and apply it to specific cases, thus allowing me to use said knowledge in my everyday life. These subjects have both nurtured and encouraged my love for reading and writing. Not only this, but they have forced me to constantly upgrade my writing style, making me unafraid of trying new formats. The subjective nature of Philosophy has dispelled my fear of "getting it wrong", which has helped me to become a better learner overall.

What else have you done outside of studies that qualifies you for this course?

In developing my interest in these two subjects, I read The Happiness Hypothesis by Jonathan Haidt. The book demonstrates how ancient philosophical ideas can be deeply examined through contemporary psychological research. Haidt's metaphor of the rider and the elephant helped me directly confront the tension between reason and emotion, a central theme in discussions of free will and agency. What I found most compelling was the book's integration of philosophical reflection with empirical study, strengthening my belief that combining psychology and philosophy yields a more nuanced understanding of the human condition.

Beyond academics, I have been an active participant in my school community. As a prefect and student council member, I developed greater confidence and leadership skills. These roles allowed me to collaborate with peers to effect positive change within the school. Serving as a diversity and mental health ambassador, I supported fellow students by: providing ongoing support, helping in organising initiatives such as culture days to help students from diverse backgrounds feel accepted. This experience broadened my understanding of mental health and wellbeing as I practiced active listening and engaged with a variety of perspectives and observed firsthand that questions of moral responsibility and care for the community are not merely theoretical, but are woven into everyday life.

Collectively, these experiences have convinced me that the intersection of psychology and philosophy offers the most robust framework for understanding the principles and lived experiences that shape human life.

feedback_items.weak_passage: There's this colonial hangover in LICs...neocolonial dependency theory where LICs are kept in the periphery for wealthier countries
feedback_items.your_feedback: I see how these tie together, but I think you could have gone into the colonial hangover stuff more, which is more interesting. Then you go straight into Solow Swan - I'm not understanding why you've brought it in to investigate how LICs can grow by hosting MNCs. Why did you name drop that without developing it? It kind of feels like you just popped it in and then left. It's not that directly applicable.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop the colonial hangover point more fully - it's more interesting. Either fully explain why Solow Swan is relevant to MNCs and development, or remove the name drop. Don't mention theories without proper explanation.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I doubted whether globalisation could continue to influence development...Altman at this paper shows that deglobalization remains a risk
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't think that's as of yet that much of a talking point. So are you saying globalisation is going to influence or deglobalization is at this point only a risk? The writing needs to be slightly adjusted because it doesn't quite make sense. I'm not sure about this conclusion you've drawn.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify your position: are you arguing globalization will continue to drive development, or that deglobalization is a threat? Make your thesis clear. The current logic is contradictory.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In this essay, you say that LICs can escape their postcolonial legacy. But then you're warning that the emergence of regional trade alliances may become a more attractive alternative to MNCs
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'm not quite understanding that. Are you saying that's a problem? Are you saying that's a problem because globalisation will lean more towards deglobalization and so that's no longer going to influence development? You haven't made your thesis point or what argument you're trying to make very clear. It's such a nuanced thing and very unclear what point you're trying to prove.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: State your thesis clearly upfront. Explain whether regional trade alliances helping LICs is good or bad in your framework. Connect this back to your main argument about development and globalization.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You're moving between theories and points very quickly without really developing them. It's hard to keep track of what you're trying to say. The logical flow is questionable in places and it feels like you're trying to force papers to work with the argument you're trying to make, and it's not working.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Slow down. Develop each theory fully before moving to the next. Make clear connections between points. Ensure theories actually support your argument rather than forcing them to fit.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This mathematics course introduced me to linear regression analysis
feedback_items.your_feedback: That is actually quite a basic thing. You don't need to say from that entire course you got linear regression analysis - it's like saying I learned differentiation. It's a core concept. Maybe bring out a more interesting thing from there.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Don't highlight basic mathematical concepts as achievements. Find something more advanced or interesting from the course to discuss.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Then you talk about the Taylor rule
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've actually explained the Taylor rule slightly incorrectly, so if you wanted to take another look at that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Review and correct your explanation of the Taylor rule. Ensure technical accuracy for all economic concepts.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Then you jump straight into the deficit myth, Kelton's deficit myth, and it restricts currency pegs and unions
feedback_items.your_feedback: You jump between topics too quickly. I need you to develop out these points more. I know you're worried about characters, but I think you can cut characters elsewhere. These paragraphs are huge but I'm not seeing why they're equal to the others. These two should be much larger.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop each economic point fully. Don't jump between deficit myth, currency pegs, etc. without proper explanation. These academic paragraphs need to be longer and more developed.

feedback_items.weak_passage: high marginal propensity to save in LICs
feedback_items.your_feedback: You'll actually find that in LICs, typically you'll see low marginal propensities to save because they can't afford to save. So a couple of theory issues there as well.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Correct this fundamental error. LICs typically have LOW marginal propensity to save due to poverty. Check all economic theory for accuracy.

feedback_items.your_feedback: If you've got this amount of heavy theory in these paragraphs, you can't afford to be doing it in this condensed way because it's just not working. Currently it's an immediate red flag for Imperial, LSE, and Cambridge.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand these theoretical paragraphs significantly. Check theory accuracy throughout. Send revised version for theory checking. Cannot submit in current state for competitive universities.

feedback_items.weak_passage: connecting the baking business to the fact that gives you a unique insight into the volatility of global supply chains
feedback_items.your_feedback: I think that's a bit of a push, a bit of a stretch. Unless you're gonna explain more apart from just saying the surge in the price of ingredients, I get you're trying to build a story, but I don't think it's necessary. You can just get straight into it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either properly develop the connection between your baking business and supply chain economics with specific analysis, or remove this attempt at personal storytelling and get straight to the economic point.

feedback_items.weak_passage: the trials in Hyderabad testing effects of microfinance revealed little impact on income diverging from the scheme's success in Pakistan
feedback_items.your_feedback: This kind of point is such a simplification of what those trials and papers were actually researching. I think it's almost offensive to them. 'This demonstrated to me the need for contextualised policymaking in LICs' - that's quite obvious as a point. I don't really like this paragraph. You haven't really understood. I don't think they're gonna like this one.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either engage properly with the nuance of the microfinance research and explain the actual findings in detail, or remove this paragraph entirely. The simplification is a red flag.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This paragraph is a bit of a simplification. You should reduce this paragraph down and instead expand upon the other two because they actually have inherently more interesting content. It's just poorly explained or there's theory incorrect in certain places.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Significantly shorten or remove this microfinance paragraph. Reallocate space to properly developing the earlier theoretical paragraphs which have better content but need expansion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: senior math challenge, UMT...contesting, challenging emotions and opposing views
feedback_items.your_feedback: The last paragraph is a little bit long for what it is. I wonder if you could speak to your tutor about having some of this in your reference. This is in every single statement. If you're gonna take up space with this, you'd be much better off expanding some of the other paragraphs. When you say you are contesting, challenging emotions and opposing views without explaining what those views are and what you challenged, it doesn't add a whole lot.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move extracurricular achievements to reference. Remove vague claims about challenging views unless you'll explain specifically what views and what your challenge was. Use space for academic content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: leadership skills
feedback_items.your_feedback: Especially at Imperial, LSE, and Cambridge, they're not going to care about leadership skills at all. Increasingly these universities don't care about that for economics, which is the most competitive course after computer science. There's fewer admissions exams in most cases, so the statement is gonna matter a lot.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove soft skills and leadership mentions entirely for competitive economics applications. Focus entirely on economic theory, analysis, and academic engagement.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to rework some of these paragraphs. There's name dropping without explanation, questionable logical flow, questionable theory application, and at points it feels like you're forcing papers to work with your argument and it's not working. I'm trying to clean up these things because you're on the cusp of really good understanding and interesting things - it's just not quite getting there.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Major revision needed: (1) Fix all theory errors (Taylor rule, MPS in LICs), (2) Develop all theoretical points fully without rushing, (3) Cut or completely rework microfinance paragraph, (4) Clarify thesis and logical flow throughout, (5) Remove extracurricular content and expand academic paragraphs. Can send revised version for theory checking.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just my opinion, so definitely have your teachers look at it and they can agree or disagree. If you like what you've got here, I'm not telling you not to do it, because you still come across as a very high level student. But that would be my two cents based on the statement. You'd benefit quite a lot from looking at some of those points again.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Get second opinion from teachers. Recognize you have strong potential but current execution has significant issues. Worth the effort to revise given your level.
